text: we're based in London right in the
centre in Somerset house and we create
an on-demand manufacturing platform to
enable businesses to offer customisation
to their customers and bring it through
the entire supply chain as well
people the opportunity to customize
garments so we started off in knitwear
but we've also moved into print and we
also do some embroidery as well we work
with big brands so multinational brands
from all over the world and we and work
with them in building into their
websites so their consumers can go onto
their site play around with something
whether it's changing a name a dynamic
pattern whatever it might be which fits
in with the brand's DNA and then once
it's purchased it gets sent direct to
manufacture
we then made what we've done is we've
built the tech
so we can actually change that how the
Machine files get sent to the machine so
we can see like what material you're
wanting to use what machining is sending
it to which factory is it and it can
actually make the manufacturing program
which you specifically needs so it's
taking that step further so it's not
just assembly and how something's made
it's actually looking at how do you make
the actual structure of the fiber
well there's myself and two co-founders
Hal and Ben they both have backgrounds
in engineering whereas my background is
in fashion particularly in knitwear but
we all met through the Royal College of
Art in London where we all were studying
design in different forms and off the
back of that we were working on a
project where we were looking at
athletes clothing and actually the
problems of getting things custom-made
for these athletes because they need
very specific performance and obviously
they've all got their very individual
body shapes and how to be able to do
that was really difficult and Hal and
Ben just couldn't fathom how it was so
hard to be able to produce these
individual garments so we started to
look at how we could make things which
were individual each time so it was much
more aligned with other industries such
as if you want to make a one-off
prototype in I don't know a PCB or
something you can design a lot of it at
home using the specific software that
anyone can use once you've had a bit of
training and how we could reflect that
into the fashion industry
there isn't really been any change just
within the fashion industry like our
actual like how the supply chain works
hasn't changed that much since the 1960s
when it was optimized for unit cost so
our view I made is that we're now ready
for the next transformation since the
end of mass production and mass
consumption and it's about making unique
items only once an order has been
created and purchased
